Industrial: growth cools, but last-mile and small-bay hold value

After pandemic-era surges, 2024 brought slower leasing velocity and rising vacancy in Greater Boston industrial. A year-end report showed Metro Boston vacancy around the high-single digits, up from the lows, with big-box product in outlying parks the softest. Even so, small-bay and last-mile space inside the Route 128/95 ring stayed tighter because urban distribution is still costly to replace, and infill sites are scarce. Nationally, rents proved sticky even as vacancy rose, thanks to reduced new starts and replacement costs. For investors, the best industrial targets in 2024 were under-managed small-bay parks, older cinder-block buildings with clear-height flexibility, and covered-land plays near truck routes where future redevelopment adds an option value.

That strengthens the case for scarce, well-located urban-infill industrial in Boston, even when headline vacancy rises across the metro.

Significant patterns observed

Supply inelasticity keeps a floor under housing. Geography and regulation restrict housing supply around Boston, which supports prices and rents even when mortgage rates are high. That pattern persisted throughout 2024. 

Quality bifurcation in office. Hybrid work shifted demand toward best-in-class space and away from commodity buildings. Utilization rose from pandemic lows but did not fully recover, reinforcing a two-tier office market. 



Life-science cyclicality on top of structural strength. The cluster remains a long-run advantage, but 2024 saw rising lab availability and slower leasing. This rewarded patient, experienced sponsors and conservative assumptions.
